awd_abstract_narration:
Some of the most serious crimes investigated by the legal system involve adults' memories of traumatic childhood experiences. Laws that permit adults to initiate criminal and civil actions about childhood victimization have raised scientific and legal interest in eyewitness identification of persons involved in acts that occurred decades ago. The present study will help guide theory and application when adults exposed to early trauma are asked to identify perpetrators of legally relevant actions experienced in childhood. The justice system will profit from development of scientifically based techniques to better ensure the accuracy of eyewitness identifications after long delays. The study will also aid the judiciary by providing guidance about the validity of techniques in cases where victims are asked to identify perpetrators from childhood.

This research examines whether false identifications can be minimized through scientifically based techniques incorporated into a widely used, science-based interview protocol, called the Cognitive Interview. The research goals are to examine: (a) effects of the Cognitive Interview with mental and context reinstatement on eyewitness identification in adults who have documented histories of childhood trauma; (b) effects of prior interviews and lineups in childhood versus no initial interviews or lineups on adults' long-term recognition memory; and (c) individual-difference predictors of photo identification accuracy after a 20 year delay. The research benefits from a prospective-longitudinal study of a large sample of child victims. Researchers will collect a second wave of data (Time 2) on these participants assessed earlier as children (Time 1). Participants' abilities to correctly identify Time 1 individuals will be assessed at Time 2 along with the participants' confidence of the identifications. Individual differences measured at Time 1 and 2 will be analyzed to determine predictors of accuracy. This innovative project provides much needed longitudinal information on eyewitness memory in adults with histories of childhood trauma.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to investigate the accuracy of eyewitness identifications after a two-decade long delay. The research examined if false identifications can be minimized through science-based strategies. In the 1990s (Time 1), 3- to 16-year-old children had been temporarily placed by authorities in a residential/medical forensic unit, not due to illness but rather for child maltreatment assessments. During the 5-day evaluation, the children experienced an anogenital medical examination by a doctor and nurse on Day 2 and a clinical/forensic interview by a psychologist to assess trauma exposure on either Day 3 or 4. For many of the children, their memory, including photo identifications of the doctor, nurse, and psychologist, was measured before they left the forensic unit.

Twenty years later (Time 2), 121 of the children, now adults (80 females), were located, interviewed, and administered Time 2 photo lineups. The majority of these participants, as at Time 1, were African American (85 African Americans; 36 non-African Americans). The major goals of the research were to examine: (a) the effects on eyewitness identifications of the Cognitive Interview with either mental reinstatement techniques alone or mental reinstatement techniques combined with context reinstatement, as compared to a typical police interview. (The Cognitive Interview consists of a set of science-based techniques to obtain the most complete and accurate reports from adults.); (b) the effects of a photo identification task in childhood on long-term identification accuracy; and (c) individual-difference predictors of false identifications after a long delay. Unconscious transference (i.e., the psychologist falsely identified as having been at the medical examination) and cross-racial identification effects were also examined.

Results revealed that, after 20 years, few adults correctly identified the doctor (0.8%) or nurse (1.7%) from the childhood medical exam. About one third (38.0%) of the participants made a false identification in either the doctor (25.8%) or nurse (20.9%) photo lineups, and 12 (10.2%) of them made false identifications in both lineups. Most participants utilized a conservative response strategy (e.g., saying the person was not pictured or saying "don't know") when answering the photo lineup questions (for the doctor lineup, 73.3%; and for the nurse lineup, 77.4%). The type of interview protocol (the Cognitive Interview vs. a police protocol) did not significantly affect correct identifications.

Regarding false identifications, having experienced a Time 1 photo identification task increased false identifications at Time 2. For participants with a history of severe sexual trauma or high post-traumatic stress scores, the Cognitive Interview with mental and context reinstatement combined resulted in a greater number of false identifications after the 20-year delay. There was no unconscious transference effect. Finally, participants whose race was the same as the doctor's were less likely to make a false identification to a doctor lineup at Time 2 than those participants whose race did not match their doctor's race. This is the first known study involving a long delay demonstrating a cross-racial effect on false identifications.

Limitations of this study include that the doctor, nurse, and psychologist were briefly seen across the 5-day stay at the unit: For the children, the professionals' familiarity was not comparable to that of family members or other well-known adults, as is common in many types of legal actions, such as in historic child maltreatment cases.

The intellectual merits include advances in theory and empirical knowledge about predictors of long-term memory in adults with histories of child abuse or neglect. The broader impacts are for eyewitness identifications from photo lineups of briefly seen adults in legal cases of historic child maltreatment.
